datasetPresenter.name: tcruSylvioX10-1_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Trypanosoma cruzi Sylvio X10/1 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: Trypanosoma cruzi Sylvio X10 was sequenced to 30X coverage using 454 and Illumina HiSeq technologies. The Illumina and 454 reads were assembled separately and subsequently merged to produce 38 Mb genome in 27,019 contigs with an N50 of 2307. EuPathDB downloaded the data from GenBank.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Trypanosoma brucei TREU927 sequence and annotation
datasetPresenter.description: The Trypanosoma brucei TREU927 sequence and annotation were downloaded from Sanger.

datasetPresenter.name: lbraMHOMBR75M2904_massSpec_promastigotes_secreted_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Proteomic analysis of conditioned medium from L. braziliensis incubations.
datasetPresenter.description: Secreted proteins, precipitated from media after incubating with L. braziliensis IOC-L 2463 promastigotes, were resuspended and analyzed by 2DE, LC-MS/MS. Peptide discovery was performed against NCBI nonredundant database (V 050623).

datasetPresenter.name: tconIL3000_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Trypanosoma congolense IL3000 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: The Trypanosoma congolense IL3000 genome was capillary-sequenced using a whole-genome shotgun strategy. EuPathDb downloaded the data from GeneDB.

datasetPresenter.name: tcruCLBrenerEsmeraldo-like_Rick_Tarleton_CNV_CGH_GFF_RSRC
datasetPresenter.description: Comprarative genomic hybridizations of 16 T. cruzi strains using CL-Brener as reference revealed significant copy number variations between strains. For each organism, genomic DNA from epimatigotes was sonicated, Cy3/5 labeled and mixed probes were hybridized to custom whole genome tiling arrays.

datasetPresenter.name: ltarParrotTarII_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Leishmania tarentolae Parrot-TarII Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: The genome sequence of Leishmania tarentolae Parrot-TarII, a kinetoplastid parasite that is non-pathogenic to humans, was resolved to an average 16-fold coverage using GS-FLX, Roche 454 and Illumina technologies. After de novo assembly, sequences of specific chromosomes were built using contigs and scaffolds based on their homology to L. major. Gene identification was performed by comparing the assembled L. tarentolae genome sequence to the putative genes of L. infantum, L. major and L. braziliensis using BLAST 2.2.21.

datasetPresenter.name: ldonBPK282A1_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Leishmania donovani BPK282A1 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description:
Leishmania donovani BPK282A1 is a Nepalese strain isolated from a patient with visceral leishmaniasis. EuPathDB downloaded the genome sequence and annotation from GenBank.

Leishmania donovani BPK282A1 genome was sequenced by combining single and paired-end reads from the 454 GS FLX Titanium platform (median 22-fold coverage) with reads from Illumina Genome Analyzer (median 52-fold coverage). The 454 data were assembled de novo, and the Illumina data were used to iteratively correct errors in the consensus sequence and close gaps. The initial set of contigs—50% of which were 44.4 kb or greater (N50)—were aligned, ordered, and oriented against the L. infantum JPCM5 reference genome to produce an assembled high quality draft L. donovani genome of length 32.4 Mb containing 2154 contigs and with a final N50 of 45.5 kb. The genome was annotated by identifying orthologous genes within the L. infantum genome and transferring their annotation onto the L. donovani draft assembly.

datasetPresenter.name: tevaSTIB805_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: T. evansi STIB 805 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: Genome sequence and annotation for T. evansi STIB 805.

datasetPresenter.name: tcrumarinkelleiB7_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Trypanosoma cruzi marinkellei Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: Trypanosoma cruzi marinkellei is a bat-associated parasite of the subgenus Schizotrypanum and it is regarded as a T. cruzi subspecies. The genome was sequenced to 30X coverage using 454 and Illumina HiSeq technologies. The Illumina and 454 reads were assembled separately and subsequently merged to produce 34 Mb genome in 23,154 contigs with an N50 of 2846. EuPathDB downloaded the data from GenBank.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_massSpec_Price_Flagellar_Proteomics_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Total Flagellar Proteome from bloodstream form
datasetPresenter.summary: Comparative proteomics identifying interactive partners of Deflagellation Inducible Protein 13 (DIP13)
datasetPresenter.description: We employed the proteomic non-gel technique isobaric tag for relative and absolute quantitation (iTRAQ) to identify and compare the relative amounts of flagellar proteins in T. brucei bloodstream form parasites over-expressing T. brucei Deflagellation Inducible Protein 13 (TbDIP13) compared to the parental line. A total of 257 proteins were identified, representing the first flagellar proteome of T. brucei BSF cells. No novel proteins were identified in the DIP13 overexpressing cell extracts compared to the parental line. The data set was filtered to exclude proteins with a pI of 10.2 or greater as these are likely to be ribosomal contaminants. The remaining data set contains 184 proteins, of which 121 have previously been found in the T. brucei PCF flagellar proteome.

datasetPresenter.name: _massSpec_Marchini_phosphoproteome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Phsophoproteome of the T. cruzi differentiation process from non-infective epimastigotes to infective metacyclic trypomastigotes.
datasetPresenter.description: The phosphoproteome during metacyclogenesis was determined by analyzing five T. cruzi Dm28c time points during the differentiation process: epimastigotes, 30 min stressed cells, 2 hr stressed cells, 12 hr stressed cells, and metacyclic trypomastigotes. Peptide digests from each time point were enriched for phosphopeptides using TiO2 chromatography and analyzed by NanoLC-MS/MS. Proteins were identified using Mascot and MaxQuant.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_massSpec_Urbaniak_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Comparison of total proteome to the kinase-enriched proteome in T. brucei 427
datasetPresenter.description: Whole cell lysates of bloodstream form Trypanosoma brucei 427 MITat1.4 were solubilised with 0.8% NP-40, centrifuged at 145,000 x g for 1 h and the supernatant enriched using kinobeads (mixed immobilised ATP-mimic kinase inhibitors) prior to reductive alkylation, tryptic digest, and analysis by LC-MS/MS.

datasetPresenter.name: _massSpec_Almaida_SUMOylation_Proteomics_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: SUMOylated proteome of T. cruzi CL Brenner epimastigotes
datasetPresenter.summary: Protein targets of SUMOylation in T. cruzi CL Brenner epimastigotes
datasetPresenter.description: SUMOylation enriched protein samples were prepared by affinity chromatography from a T. cruzi CL Brenner epimastigote cell line expressing TcSUMO (test) or from wild type cells (mock). Proteins were analyzed by two-dimensional LC-MS/MS, compared between test and mock samples, and quantified using a spectral count approach. (SUMO = small ubiquitin-like modifier)

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_massSpec_Urbaniak_CompProt_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Comparative proteomics of bloodstream and procyclic forms
datasetPresenter.summary: Comparison of T. brucei 427 procyclic and bloodstream form trypanosomes via SILAC proteomic analysis.
datasetPresenter.description: Procyclic form Trypanosoma brucei clone 29.13.6 cells were grown in modified SDM-79 medium containing L-Arginine.HCl U-13C6 and L-Lysine.2HCl U-13C6 (heavy label) and bloodstream form Trypanosoma brucei 427 MITat1.2 were grown in HMI-9T. Cells were hypotonically lysed at 5 × 109 cells/mL, equal cell numbers mixed, and the combined suspension solubilized in 4% SDS at 95°C prior to washing with 8 M urea and reductive alkylation. Proteins were separated by SDS-PAGE prior to in-gel tryptic digest, or treated with trypsin in solution and the peptides fractionated by strong cation exchange prior to analysis by LC-MS/MS. Data are presented as Log2 Fold-change Pcf/Bsf with a 1% false discovery rate; where no ratio is reported, one could not be accurately determined.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_massSpec_Hill_Flagellum_Surface_And_Matrix_Proteomes_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Bloodstream form Flagellum Surface and Matrix Proteomes
datasetPresenter.summary: Flagellum surface and matrix proteomes from T. brucei bloodstream form trypanosomes.
datasetPresenter.description: Lateral flagellar connections to the T. brucei bloodstream form cell body were removed by tetracycline induced RNAi against fla1. Whole cells were surface biotinylated and intact, membrane enclosed flagella were isolated by shearing. Soluble, surface flagellar proteins were separtated from matrix proteins by streptavidin affinity chrmoatography. MudPIT analysis revealed 158 surface proteins and 666 matrix proteins.

datasetPresenter.name: linfJPCM5_Mottram_Jeremy_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Promastigote transcriptome of L. infantum JPCM5 by mRNA-Seq
datasetPresenter.description: The promastigote transcriptome of L. infantum JPCM5 was determined by mRNA sequencing using single-end Illumina protocols.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_Archer_Stuart_CellCycle_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Gene expression profiling of the T. brucei cell cycle by RNA-sequencing.
datasetPresenter.description:
Analysis of gene expression over the Trypanosoma brucei cell cycle was performed by measuring changes in mRNA abundance on a transcriptome-wide scale. A Double-Cut Elutriation (DCE) procedure was developed to select unperturbed, highly synchronous cell populations from log-phase cultures, and this was compared with synchronization by starvation.

Cell populations were isolated from four time-points post-selection: early (0.5 hours) and late (3 hours) G1 phase, S-phase (5.5 hours), and G2 phase (7.25 hours), each population consisting almost entirely of the desired cell cycle stage. Poly-A+ RNA from these cells was selected and subjected to expression profiling by RNA-seq. Between 13 and 17 million high-quality reads per time-point could be mapped to the T. brucei genome.

datasetPresenter.name: lbraMHOMBR75M2904_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Leishmania braziliensis M2904 (MHOM/BR/75M2904) sequence and annotation from GeneDB.
datasetPresenter.description:
This resource includes chromosome sequences and annotations for Leishmania braziliensis. Sequence data for Leishmania braziliensis M2904 (MHOM/BR/75M2904) were downloaded from GeneDB (sequence and annotated features).


L. (Viannia) braziliensis M2904 (MHOM/BR/75M2904) is a reference strain from Evandro Chagas Institute, Belém, Brazil. This strain was isolated by direct culture from a lesion on the right side of the thorax of a man who had been performing survey work in Serra dos Carajás, Brazilian Amazonia.


The LB2904 clone is infective in hamsters and BALB/c mice and can be genetically transfected and cloned on plates.


Sequencing of L. braziliensis was conducted by The Sanger Institute pathogen sequencing unit.

datasetPresenter.name: lmajSD75.1_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Genome sequence and annotation for Leishmania major SD 75.1
datasetPresenter.description:
Leishmania major strain SD 75.1 genome from WUSTL.

The Leishmania major (MHOM/SN/74/SD) was obtained from David Sacks (NIH). The properties of this line are described in here. A clonal derivative (75.1) was prepared by Deborah E. Dobson (Washington University School of Medicine) and used for sequencing.

Genomic DNA was made by CsCl/Ethidium bromide density gradient centrifugation to minimize the amount of kinetoplast (mitochondrial) DNA; this was prepared by Natalia Akopyants (Washington University School of Medicine).

Next-generation sequences on the 454 instruments were produced for a draft assembly. Total sequence coverage of 454 instrument reads was ~31X (Fragments 19X, 3Kb PE 9X, 8Kb PE 3X) using a genome size estimate of 40Mb. The combined sequence reads were assembled using the Newbler software (Roche 454). This first draft assembly was referred to as L_major_SD_1.0. This version has been cleaned of contaminants. The assembly is made up of a total of 1904 scaffolds with an N50 scaffold length of over 691kb (N50 contig length for the 4009 contigs was 27kb). The assembly spans 30.8Mb.

This work was supported by NIH grants AI29646 and AI 31078 to SMB and by NIH-NHGRI grant 5U54HG00307907 to RKW, Director of The Genome Center at Washington University.

For questions regarding this L_major_SD_1.0 assembly please contact Dr. Wes Warren, Washington University School of Medicine (wwarren@watson.wustl.edu). Downloads of the sequence data are available via the TriTrypDB genome browser server. Funding for the sequence characterization of the Leishmania major (strain/isolate SD 75.1) genome was provided by the National Human Genome Research Institute (NHGRI), National Institutes of Health (NIH).

DNA source - Drs. Stephen M. Beverley & Natalia Akopyants, Department of Molecular Microbiology, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.

Sequencing - The Genome Center, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO. Sequence assembly – The Genome Center, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO. Citation upon use of this assembly in a manuscript:

It is requested that users of this Leishmania major (strain/isolate SD 75.1) sequence assembly acknowledge Stephen M. Beverley and The Genome Center, Washington University School of Medicine in any publications that result from use of this sequence assembly. Any publications that propose to use whole genome or chromosome data should contact The Genome Center at Washington University (gweinsto@wustl.edu or wwarren@wustl.edu) for the use of pre-publication data. Please refer to the Genome Center Data Use Policy for further information regarding proper use of data and proper citation.

Fragment spectra were searched against the L. major (May 2006 compilation, 17392 sequences) protein database using Mascot (v2.2, Matrix Science).

datasetPresenter.description: Metacyclic trypomastigotes, amastigotes, trypomastigotes, and epimastigotes of T. cruzi Brazil were isolated and proteins were extracted from whole-cell or subcellular lysates. Digested peptides from protein preparations were analyzed by offline LC, and online LC-MS/MS.

datasetPresenter.description: Cellular proteins were extracted from axenic promastigotes, amastigotes, and differentiating parasites and analyzed by iTRAQ analysis. The identified peptides were analyzed to detect post-translationally modified amino acids. Peptide spectra were screened against the L. infantum V3.0 genome from GeneDB.

datasetPresenter.description: A mitochondria enriched protein fraction was prepared from Trypanosoma brucei procyclic form cells Detergent soluble fractions were trypsin digested and the resulting peptides were analyzed by 2D-LC-MS/MS. Insoluble fractions were dissolved in 1X SDS-PAGE buffer and analyzed by 1D-LC-MS/MS. The mass spectrometry data was analyzed against T. brucei sequence databases using SEQUEST

Fractions from FFE were pooled and analyzed by 1DE- or 2DE- LC-MS/MS.

datasetPresenter.name: lmajFriedlin_chipChipExper_Peter_Myler_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: The chromosomal location of TATA-binding protein (TBP or TRF4), Small Nuclear Activating Protein complex (SNAP50), and H3 histones were assessed in Leishmania major using microarrays hybridized with DNA obtained through chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP-chip). The TBP and SNAP50 binding patterns were almost identical and high intensity peaks were associated with tRNAs and snRNAs. Only 184 peaks of acetylated H3 histone were found in the entire genome, with substantially higher intensity in rapidly-dividing cells than stationary-phase. The majority of the acetylated H3 peaks were found at divergent strand-switch regions, but some occurred at chromosome ends and within polycistronic gene clusters. Almost all these peaks were associated with lower intensity peaks of TBP/SNAP50 binding a few kilobases upstream, evidence that they represent transcription initiation sites. Contact Peter Myler, peter.myler@sbri.org, Seattle Biomedical Research Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_George_Cross_Splice_Leader_rnaSeqSplicedLeaderAndPolyASites_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Splice Leader and Poly A Sites from RNASeq
datasetPresenter.summary: Curated splice sites provided by George Cross.
datasetPresenter.description: Curated splice sites provided by George Cross. RNAseq data from bloodstream and procyclic Lister 427 and procyclic TREU 927 were put through several filters prior to final manual curation. Most importantly, only tags that contained the last 14 contiguous nucleotides of the SL and were > 13 nt long after removing all of the SL sequence and adding "AG" to the 5-prime end, and gave unique and perfect matches (32 or 36 bp sequences: 2 mismatches were allowed for 76-bp sequences) on the correct strand, with at least 2 hits per splice-acceptor sites (SAS), were retained. Data for 6,959 genes (10,857 SAS) met these criteria. Data from bloodstream and procyclic forms were merged.

link.text: Detailed curated data, with independent values for bloodstream and procyclic forms available for download as an EXCEL file

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_sageTag_DGETag_frequencies_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary:
Frequencies of tags that were observed in studies using RNA from T. brucei gambiense.

The digital gene expression (DGE) tags represent a 21 bp tag usually from the first NlaIII restriction site upstream of the poly A tail on mRNA transcript. A detailed description of the method and experiment is available in Veitch et al ( Veitch NJ, Johnson PCD, Trivedi U, Terry S, Wildridge D and MacLeod A. Digital gene expression analysis of two life-cycle stages of the human-infective parasite, Trypanosoma brucei gambiense reveals differentially expressed clusters of co-regulated genes. BMC Genomics, 2010, 11:124-137). DGE tags were created from three procyclic-form and three bloodstream-form Trypanosoma brucei gambiense STIB386 in vitro cultures. The 21bp tags have been aligned to the T.b.brucei 927 and T.b.gambiense Dal genome databases, allowing for up to a 2 bp mismatch. Tags that only align once to the genome are represented, so tags that are not unique are not present. The differential expression of bloodstream-form versus procyclic-form T.b.gambiense DGE tags is available to view for each tag.

Publication is available from the PubMed http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20175885

Digital gene expression analysis of two life cycle stages of the human-infective parasite, Trypanosoma brucei gambiense reveals differentially expressed clusters of co-regulated genes. BMC Genomics. 2010 Feb 22;11:124.

datasetPresenter.name: cfasCfCl_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: Crithidia fasciculata Cf-C1 sequence
datasetPresenter.description:
The Crithidia fasciculata Cf-C1 was obtained from Dr. Larry Simpson, University of California, Los Angeles. Genomic DNA was prepared by CsCl/Ethidium bromide density gradient centrifugation to rminimize the amount of kinetoplast (mitochondrial) DNA, and was provided by Drs. Natalia Akopyants, Lon-Fye Lye and Stephen Beverley, Washington University School of Medicine.

A combination of next-generation sequencing and Sanger reads were produced for a draft assembly. Total sequence coverage of 454 instrument reads was 26X (Fragments 10X, 3Kb PE 14X, 8Kb PE 2X) and Sanger reads was .75X using a genome size estimate of 40Mb. The combined sequence reads were assembled using the CABOG software (Bioinformatics 24:2818-2824 2008). This first draft assembly was referred to as Crithidia_9.0. This version has been cleaned of contaminants and had some remaining vector trimmed from contigs. The assembly is made up of a total of 1043 scaffolds with an N50 scaffold length of over 122kb (N50 contig length for the 2847 contigs was 28kb). The assembly spans 34.5Gb.

This work was supported by NIH grant AI29646 to SMB and by NIH-NHGRI grant 5U54HG00307907 to RKW, Director of The Genome Center at Washington University.

For questions regarding this Crithidia fasciculata assembly please contact Dr. Wes Warren, Washington University School of Medicine (wwarren@watson.wustl.edu). Downloads of the sequence data are available via the TriTrypDB genome browser server. Funding for the sequence characterization of the Crithidia fasciculata genome was provided by the National Human Genome Research Institute (NHGRI), National Institutes of Health (NIH).

DNA source - Drs. Stephen Beverley, Natalia Akopyants, and Lon-Fye Lye, Department of Microbiology, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.

Sequencing - The Genome Center, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.

Sequence assembly - The Genome Center, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.

It is requested that users of this Crithidia sequence assembly acknowledge Stephen M. Beverley and The Genome Center, Washington University School of Medicine in any publications that result from use of this sequence assembly. Any publications that propose to use whole genome or chromosome data should contact the Genome Center at Washington University (gweinsto@wustl.edu or wwarren@wustl.edu) for the use of pre-publication data. Please refer to the Genome Center Data Use Policy for further information regarding proper use of data and proper citation.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_microarrayExpression_E-MEXP-1476_heat_shock_stress_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Procyclic trypanosomes treated with heat shock
datasetPresenter.summary: Expression profiles of heat shock treated procyclic trypansosomes compared to untreated control.
datasetPresenter.description: Procyclic trypanosomes (strain 427 lister) were grown in culture under standard conditions at 27°C in SDM79 medium with 10% foetal bovine serume (Brun and Schnenberger, 1979), in a gazed incubator (5% CO2). Logarithmically growing procyclic cells (at about 5*10^6 cells/ml, at 27°C) were added to one volume medium that had been heated to 53°C and incubated at 41°C for 60 minutes in a waterbath in a closed tube (41°C sample). The control cells were added to one volume medium at 27°C and also incubated for 60 minutes in a closed tube at 27°C. Cells were harvested and washed once in PBS. The harvesting was done within 8 minutes.

templateInjector.prop: heat shock data versus the control

datasetPresenter.name: tbruLister427_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary: DNA was isolated (Nicolai Siegel and Oliver Dreesen) from cultured bloodstream forms of Trypanosoma brucei strain Lister 427 containing various transgenes, and prepared for single-ended sequencing by Illumina and 454 technologies, which yielded read lengths of 76bp and 350bp (average) respectively. The sequences were assembled (George Cross) using individual chromosomes of the genome reference strain Trypanosoma brucei TREU (Trypanosomiasis Research Edinburgh University) 927/4 as templates and SeqMan NGen software (DNASTAR). The assemblies were evaluated and annotations were transferred from the genome reference strain TREU 927 by Matthew Rogers of The Sanger Institute pathogen sequencing unit.

datasetPresenter.name: tcruEsmeraldo_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary:
The Trypanosoma cruzi Esmeraldo strain cl3 was obtained from Dr. Gregory Buck, Center for the Study of Biological Complexity, Microbiology and Immunology, Virginia Commonwealth University.

This strain, a representative of the TcII lineage of T. cruzi (Brisse et al., 2000, Zingales et al., 2009), was isolated from a male patient, age ~20, in acute stage of disease (fatal) in Sao Felipe, Bahia, Brazil in 1971. The properties of T. cruzi Esmeraldo are described in Miles et al., 1977. A clonal derivative was prepared from epimastigote culture by single cell manipulation by M.A.Miles. and used for sequencing.

Genomic DNA was depleted for kinetoplast (mitochondrial) DNA (kDNA), which represents up to 30-50% of the total DNA in the cell, by Andrey Matveyev. In brief, total DNA was extracted from cultured late log phase T. cruzi Esmeraldo epimastigote forms and submitted to low voltage electrophoresis in 0.8% low melting agarose. The gDNA-containing agarose blocks were excised from the gel, leaving the kDNA networks intact in the gel. Purified gDNA was recovered from the agarose blocks after digestion using Beta-agarase I.

The gDNA was fragmented and sequenced using the Roche 454 FLX Titanium technology and a draft assembly was produced. Total sequence coverage from the Roche 454 technology was ~63X (fragments ~47X, 3 Kb paired end (PE) ~11X, 8 Kb PE ~5X) using a genome size estimate of 40 Mbp. The combined sequence reads were assembled using the Newbler software (Roche 454). This first draft assembly was referred to as T_cruzi_Esmeraldo_5.1. This version has been cleaned of contaminants. The assembly is made up of a total of 23,808 scaffolds with an N50 scaffold length of over 52kb (N50 contig length for the 31,945 contigs was 3.3kb). The assembly spans 35.5Mb. This assembly is subject to change due to ongoing assembly improvement efforts.

This work was supported by NSF DEB-0830056 grant to Gregory Buck and by NIH-NHGRI grant 5U54HG00307907 to RKW, Director of The Genome Center at Washington University.

For questions regarding this T_cruzi_Esmeraldo_5.1 assembly please contact Dr. Wes Warren, Washington University School of Medicine (wwarren@watson.wustl.edu). Downloads of the sequence data are available via the TriTrypDB genome browser server. Funding for the sequence characterization of the Trypanosoma cruzi Esmeraldo strain cI3 genome was provided by the National Human Genome Research Institute (NHGRI), National Institutes of Health (NIH).

datasetPresenter.name: lbraMHOMBR75M2903_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary:
Background

The Leishmania brazilensis M2903 strain was isolated in 1975 from a cutaneous lesion of a man who contracted the infection in a forested area of Serra dos Carajas, Para State, Brazil (J. Shaw, personal communication; cited in Balanco et al. Parisitology (1998) 116: 103-113).


The WHO strain designation is MHOM/BR/75/M2903. Dr. J. Shaw kindly made this strain available for sequencing, with the assistance of Diane McMahon-Pratt (Yale School of Public Health).


RT-PCR typing with several primer sets shows that this line lacks detectable levels of LRV1 virus. This strain can be readily manipulated genetically and possesses a potent RNAi activity. (Lye, L-F., K. L. Owens, H. Shi, S.M.F. Murta, A.C. Vieira, S.J. Turco, C. Tschudi, E. Ullu, and S.M. Beverley (2010), Retention and loss of RNA interference pathways in Trypanosomatid protozoans, Plos Pathogens 6: e1001161. PMCID: PMC2965760). It is infective in various animal models according to the literature and in work in the Beverley laboratory.


Genomic DNA was made by CsCl/Ethidium bromide density gradient centrifugation to minimize the amount of kinetoplast (mitochondrial) DNA.


Next-generation sequences on the 454 instruments were produced for a draft assembly. Total sequence coverage of 454 instrument reads was ~68X (Fragments 22X, 3Kb PE 28X, 8Kb PE 17X) using a genome size estimate of 40Mb. The combined sequence reads were assembled using the Newbler software (Roche 454). This first draft assembly was referred to as L_brazilensis_M2903_1.0.1. This version has been cleaned of contaminants. The assembly is made up of a total of 4410 scaffolds with an N50 scaffold length of over 737kb (N50 contig length for the 7215 contigs was 17kb). The assembly spans 33Mb.


This work was supported by NIH grants AI29646 and AI 31078 to SMB and by NIH-NHGRI grant 5U54HG00307907 to RKW, Director of The Genome Center at Washington University.


For questions regarding this L_brazilensis_M2903_1.0.1 assembly please contact Dr. Wes Warren, Washington University School of Medicine (wwarren@watson.wustl.edu). Downloads of the sequence data are available via the TriTrypDB genome browser server. Funding for the sequence characterization of the Leishmania brazilensis M2903 genome was provided by the National Human Genome Research Institute (NHGRI), National Institutes of Health (NIH).


Credits

DNA source - Drs. Stephen M. Beverley (beverley@borcim.wustl.edu) & Natalia Akopyants, Department of Molecular Microbiology, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.

LRV typing Drs. Lon-Fye Lye and Stephen M. Beverley, Department of Molecular Microbiology, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.

Sequencing - The Genome Center, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.

Sequence assembly The Genome Center, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.

datasetPresenter.name: tcruJRcl4_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.summary:
Background

The Trypanosome cruzi JR strain cl4 was obtained from Dr. Gregory Buck, Center for the Study of Biological Complexity, Microbiology and Immunology, Virginia Commonwealth University. This strain, a representative of the TcI lineage of T. cruzi (Hamilton et al., 2011), was isolated by Hernan Jose Carrasco, Institute of Tropical Medicine, Universidad Central de Venezuela, from a male patient, age 55, in chronic symptomatic stage of disease in Anzoategui, Venezuela . A clonal derivative was prepared from epimastigote culture by plating on blood agar plates (M. Lewis) and used for sequencing.


Genomic DNA was depleted for kinetoplast (mitochondrial) DNA (kDNA), which represents up to 30-50% of the total DNA in the cell, by Andrey Matveyev. In brief, total DNA was extracted from cultured late log phase T. cruzi JR epimastigote forms and submitted to low voltage electrophoresis in 0.8% low melting agarose. The gDNA-containing agarose blocks were excised from the gel, leaving the kDNA networks intact in the gel. Purified gDNA was recovered from the agarose blocks after digestion using Beta-agarase I.


The gDNA was fragmented and sequenced using the Roche 454 FLX Titanium technology and a draft assembly was produced. Total sequence coverage from the Roche 454 technology was ~50X (fragments =~ 22X, 3 Kb paired end (PE) =~ 20X, 8 Kb PE =~ 6.5X) using a genome size estimate of 40 Mbp. The combined sequence reads were assembled using the Newbler software (Roche 454). This first draft assembly was referred to as T._cruzi_JR cl4-1.1. The assembly is made up of a total of 20,846 scaffolds with an N50 scaffold length of over 67kb (N50 contig length for the 25,491 contigs was 3.9kb). The assembly spans 41Mb. This assembly is subject to change due to ongoing assembly improvement efforts.


This work was supported by NSF DEB-0830056 grant to Gregory Buck and by NIH-NHGRI grant 5U54HG00307907 to RKW, Director of The Genome Center at Washington University.


For questions regarding this T_cruzi_JR cl4-1.1_assembly please contact Dr. Wes Warren, Washington University School of Medicine (wwarren@genome.wustl.edu). Downloads of the sequence data are available via the TriTrypDB genome browser server. Funding for the sequence characterization of the Trypanosoma cruzi JR cl4 strain genome was provided by the National Human Genome Research Institute (NHGRI), National Institutes of Health (NIH).


Credits

DNA source Myrna G. Serrano, Andrey Matveyev, Ana Lara and Gregory Buck Center for the Study of Biological Complexity & the Department of Microbiology and Immunology, Virginia Commonwealth University., Richmond, VA


Parasite source Michael Miles and Michael D. Lewis, Medical Protozoology, London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine, London, England.


Hernan Jose Carrasco, Institute of Tropical Medicine, Universidad Central de Venezuela.


Sequencing - The Genome Center, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.


Sequence assembly The Genome Center, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, MO.


Citation upon use of this assembly in a manuscript

It is requested that users of this Trypanosoma cruzi JR cl4 strain sequence assembly acknowledge Gregory A. Buck, Virginia Commonwealth University, and The Genome Center, Washington University School of Medicine in any publications that result from use of this sequence assembly. Any publications that propose to use whole genome or chromosome data should contact The Genome Center at Washington University (gweinsto@wustl.edu or wwarren@wustl.edu) for the use of pre-publication data. Please refer to the Genome Center Data Use Policy (http://genome.wustl.edu/data/data_use_policy) for further information regarding proper use of data and proper citation.


Miles MA, Toye PJ, Oswald SC, Godfrey DG. The identification by isoenzyme patterns of two distinct strain-groups of Trypanosoma cruzi, circulating independently in a rural area of Brazil. Trans R Soc Trop Med Hyg. 1977; 71: 217-25.


Brisse S, Barnabé C, Tibayrenc M. Identification of six Trypanosoma cruzi phylogenetic lineages by random amplified polymorphic DNA and multilocus enzyme electrophoresis. Int J Parasitol. 2000; 30: 35-44.


Zingales B, Andrade SG, Briones MR, Campbell DA, Chiari E, Fernandes O, Guhl F, Lages-Silva E, Macedo AM, Machado CR, Miles MA, Romanha AJ, Sturm NR, Tibayrenc M, Schijman AG; Second Satellite Meeting. A new consensus for Trypanosoma cruzi intraspecific nomenclature: second revision meeting recommends TcI to TcVI. Mem Inst Oswaldo Cruz. 2009; 104: 1051-4.

datasetPresenter.name: tbruTREU927_SNP_Tb427_GeorgeCross_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Aligned HTS SNP calls for Lister strain 427
datasetPresenter.summary: High throughput sequencing SNP calls for T. brucei Lister 427 aligned to the T. brucei TREU927 reference.
datasetPresenter.description: Illumina sequence reads of T. brucei Lister strain 427 were provided by George Cross. Reads were aligned to the T. brucei TREU927 reference genome using Bowtie and SNPs called using VarScan.
